lines.text: Enter LADY MACDUFF, her Son, and ROSS

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: What had he done, to make him fly the land

lines.speaker: ross
lines.text: You must have patience, madam.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: He had none: His flight was madness: when our actions do not, Our fears do make us traitors.

lines.speaker: ross
lines.text: You know not Whether it was his wisdom or his fear.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Wisdom! to leave his wife, to leave his babes, His mansion and his titles in a place From whence himself does fly He loves us not He wants the natural touch: for the poor wren, The most diminutive of birds, will fight, Her young ones in her nest, against the owl. All is the fear and nothing is the love As little is the wisdom, where the flight So runs against all reason.

lines.speaker: ross
lines.text: My dearest coz, I pray you, school yourself: but for your husband, He is noble, wise, judicious, and best knows The fits o the season. I dare not speak much further But cruel are the times, when we are traitors And do not know ourselves, when we hold rumour From what we fear, yet know not what we fear, But float upon a wild and violent sea Each way and move. I take my leave of you: Shall not be long but Ill be here again: Things at the worst will cease, or else climb upward To what they were before. My pretty cousin, Blessing upon you!

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Fatherd he is, and yet hes fatherless.

lines.speaker: ross
lines.text: I am so much a fool, should I stay longer, It would be my disgrace and your discomfort: I take my leave at once.
Exit

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Sirrah, your fathers dead And what will you do now How will you live

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: As birds do, mother.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: What, with worms and flies

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: With what I get, I mean and so do they.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Poor bird! thouldst never fear the net nor lime, The pitfall nor the gin.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Why should I, mother Poor birds they are not set for. My father is not dead, for all your saying.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Yes, he is dead how wilt thou do for a father

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Nay, how will you do for a husband

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Why, I can buy me twenty at any market.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Then youll buy em to sell again.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Thou speakst with all thy wit: and yet, i faith, With wit enough for thee.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Was my father a traitor, mother

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Ay, that he was.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: What is a traitor

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Why, one that swears and lies.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: And be all traitors that do so

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Every one that does so is a traitor, and must be hanged.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: And must they all be hanged that swear and lie

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Every one.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Who must hang them

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Why,  the honest men.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Then the liars and swearers are fools, for there are liars and swearers enow to beat the honest men and hang up them.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Now, God help thee, poor monkey! But how wilt thou do for a father

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: If he were dead, yould weep for him: if you would not, it were a good sign that I should quickly have a new father.

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Poor prattler, how thou talkst!
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Bless you, fair dame! I am not to you known, Though in your state of honour I am perfect. I doubt some danger does approach you nearly: If you will take a homely mans advice, Be not found here hence, with your little ones. To fright you thus, methinks, I am too savage To do worse to you were fell cruelty, Which is too nigh your person. Heaven preserve you! I dare abide no longer.
Exit

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: Whither should I fly I have done no harm. But I remember now I am in this earthly world where to do harm Is often laudable, to do good sometime Accounted dangerous folly: why then, alas, Do I put up that womanly defence, To say I have done no harm What are these faces
Enter Murderers

lines.speaker: first murderer
lines.text: Where is your husband

lines.speaker: lady macduff
lines.text: I hope, in no place so unsanctified Where such as thou mayst find him.

lines.speaker: first murderer
lines.text: Hes a traitor.

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: Thou liest, thou shaghaird villain!

lines.speaker: first murderer
lines.text: What, you egg! Young fry of treachery!
Stabbing him

lines.speaker: son
lines.text: He has killd me, mother: Run away, I pray you!
Dies
Exit LADY MACDUFF, crying Murder! Exeunt Murderers, following her
